quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: Every story is about a singular moment. I call it five seconds. It's a moment of either transformation, meaning I'm telling you a story about how I once used to be one kind of person and now I'm a new kind of person. Or more common is realization. Which is I used to think something and then some stuff happened and now I think a new thing.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: If your audience isn't wondering what you're about to say, they're no longer listening to you. I assume all the time, 100% of the time, that no one wants to hear anything I have to say. And so I am relentless in my attempt to get the audience to be constantly wondering what the next sentence is.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: To be a storyteller means you have to separate yourself from the herd, and in their mind, that risks them getting picked off by some predator. But the alternative is you're in the herd, which means you're forgettable. The risk you take if you're not telling stories is that you will be forgotten. 100%. You will be forgotten.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: Our minds are not designed to remember a pie chart or facts or statistics or platitudes or ideas that are not attached to imagery. So the risk you take if you're not telling stories is that you will be forgotten.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: He got more leads at the conference than the other four scientists combined. And every single time someone at that conference goes into a grocery store and they're looking at apples, they're going to think about that company. We create positive connections with items in the world related to our company by telling stories.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: We're not going to match content to content. Instead, we're going to match theme, meaning or message. That snap when someone realizes, you were telling me about apples, but really you were telling me about tubes. That snap is so powerful.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: Every day before I go to bed, I'm going to look back on the day and find one moment that would've been worth telling as a story. I discovered that my life is filled with more stories than I will ever have time to tell. And I'm not a unicorn. Thousands of people all over the world are doing the same thing.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: In the first year I did Homework for Life I found 1.8 moments per day. I now find 7.6 moments per day. It's not because my life is more interesting. It's because I have a better lens and I understand what to look for, what to see, and what is worth remembering.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: Storytelling is not about facility with the language or your vocabulary. It's all about decision-making. Storytellers are people who think before they speak. They make strategical tactical decisions before they speak. And ultimately, they make enough good decisions to entertain people.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: 98% of your nervousness is actually before you begin speaking. Once you begin speaking, almost all of your nervousness falls away. So what you're really suffering is from pre-talk nervousness.

quotes.speaker: Matthew Dicks
quotes.text: When someone offers you an opportunity, as crazy as it is, as much as you don't want to do it, the yeses that I have said about something I did not want to do have resulted in the best and most extraordinary opportunities of my life. A yes can always become a no.

takeaways: Every great story is built around one five-second moment of transformation or realization -- find that moment first, then build the context around it.
In business, people who don't tell stories are forgettable -- our minds are wired for narrative, not pie charts, so differentiate yourself by mastering story.
Use 'adjacency' to connect stories to business -- don't match content to content; match theme, meaning, or message, then 'snap' it into place for maximum impact.
Start Homework for Life: every day, record one moment worth telling as a story -- it compounds your storytelling lens from 1.8 moments per day to 7.6 over time.
Say yes to things that scare you -- the opportunities you fear most often lead to your greatest growth, and a yes can always become a no later.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the corporate instinct to play it safe and stay in the herd -- argues that conformity guarantees being forgotten, which is the bigger risk.
A scientist who told zero data and only a story about apples outperformed four data-presenting colleagues combined -- upends the assumption that data sells.
